description: An overview of your GameLift Servers managed EC2 fleets

options.content: **Instance Type:** ${instance_type} Related dashboard: Instances overview **Note:** This dashbord is only for managed EC2 fleets. See the container fleet overview dashboard for managed container fleets Monitor key fleet metrics for potential issues: - **Global CCU & Capacity** shows active player count and available game server processes globally for the fleet. Watch for capacity constraints and player distribution across regions. - **Location CCU** displays location-specific CCU. Identify regional issues and capacity balancing needs. - **Location Capacity** displays location-specific capacity in use (%). It is the average capacity in use across all the instances in the location. Click the information icon (â“˜) next to each graph for detailed analysis and troubleshooting steps.

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the number of concurrent users in all the game servers over all the instances in all locations.

#### Why is it important?
- Shows player distribution
- Helps in capacity planning
panels.title: CCU

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the number of concurrent users in all the game servers over all the instances in all locations globally.

#### Why is it important?
- Shows player distribution
- Helps in capacity planning
panels.title: Global CCU

panels.description: #### What it means It shows the capacity utilization (%) globally, and the percentage of game servers in-use globally. #### Why is it important? - Indicates there is a bottleneck for onboarding more game sessions #### What is the root cause? - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the Instances Overview dashboard for instance metrics for other instances. Sometimes, only a single instance is bad. #### How to mitigate the issue - Consider scaling the fleet to more numbers of instances in a location, and have a look at the "Location capacity" section to identify the locations with the highest usage. - Consider increasing the number of concurrent process in the runtime configuration of the fleet.
panels.title: Global Capacity Usage

panels.description: #### What it means It shows the total number of game servers in the fleet that are ready to receive a game session. #### Why is it important? Indicates a bottleneck for onboarding more game sessions. #### What is the root cause? - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the Instances Overview dashboard for instance metrics for other instances. Sometimes, only a single instance is bad. #### How to mitigate the issue - Consider scaling the fleet to more instances in a location, and have a look at "Location capacity" section to identify the locations with the highest usage. - Consider increasing the number of concurrent process in the runtime configuration of the fleet.
panels.title: Global Capacity Available (Game servers)

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the total number of instances in the fleet that are active.

targets.sqlExpression: SELECT SUM(ActiveInstances) FROM SCHEMA("AWS/GameLift", FleetId, Location) WHERE FleetId = '$fleet_id' AND Location = 'aggregate'

panels.title: Active Instances

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the average percentage of instances in the fleet (all locations) that do not have an active game session running.

#### Why is it important?
This should be low in order to do effective cost savings.

#### How to mitigate the issue
- Identify the location that has idle capacity from the "Location Capacity" section.
- Use auto-scaling policies as mentioned in the [guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/gamelift/latest/developerguide/fleets-autoscaling.html)

targets.sqlExpression: SELECT AVG(PercentIdleInstances) FROM SCHEMA("AWS/GameLift", FleetId, Location) WHERE FleetId = '$fleet_id'

panels.title: Idle Instance %

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the number of instances in the fleet (all locations) that do not have an active game session running.

#### Why is it important?
This should be low in order to do effective cost savings.

#### How to mitigate the issue
- Identify the location that has idle capacity from the "Location Capacity" section
- Use auto-scaling policies as mentioned in the [guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/gamelift/latest/developerguide/fleets-autoscaling.html)

targets.sqlExpression: SELECT SUM(IdleInstances) FROM SCHEMA("AWS/GameLift", FleetId, Location) WHERE FleetId = '$fleet_id'

panels.title: Idle Instances

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the number of active game server processes that are ready to host a game session.

#### Why is it important?
This should be low in order to do effective cost savings.

#### How to mitigate the issue
- Identify the location that has idle capacity from the "Location Capacity" section
- Use auto-scaling policies as mentioned in the [guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/gamelift/latest/developerguide/fleets-autoscaling.html)
panels.title: Active Processes

panels.description:
#### What it means
Shows the number of instances in the fleet (all locations) that do not have an active game session running.

#### Why is it important?
This should be low in order to do effective cost savings.

#### How to mitigate the issue
- Identify the location that has idle capacity from the "Location Capacity" section
- Use auto-scaling policies as mentioned in the [guide](https://docs.aws.amazon.com/gamelift/latest/developerguide/fleets-autoscaling.html)
panels.title: Desired Instances

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the number of game sessions that started across the fleet.

targets.label: ServerProcessActivations
targets.sqlExpression: SELECT SUM(ServerProcessActivations) FROM SCHEMA("AWS/GameLift", FleetId, Location) WHERE FleetId = '$fleet_id'

panels.title: Game Server Starts

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the number of game sessions that stopped or crashed across the fleet.

targets.label: ServerProcessTerminations
targets.sqlExpression: SELECT SUM(ServerProcessTerminations) FROM SCHEMA("AWS/GameLift", FleetId, Location) WHERE FleetId = '$fleet_id'

panels.title: Game Server Stops

panels.description: #### What it means It shows the average percentage of game servers that report healthy to Amazon GameLift Servers across the fleet. #### Why is it important? If the game servers are not healthy, no game sessions would be placed on them #### How to mitigate the issue - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the Instances Overview dashboard for instance metrics. For other instances, sometimes a only single instance is bad.

targets.sqlExpression: SELECT AVG(PercentHealthyServerProcesses) FROM SCHEMA("AWS/GameLift", FleetId, Location) WHERE FleetId = '$fleet_id' GROUP BY Location

panels.title: Healthy Game Servers (%)

panels.description: #### What it means It shows the number of game servers that crashed across the fleet. #### Why is it important? A high number of game session crashes causes bad player experiences alongside resource waste and unwanted noise. #### How to mitigate the issue - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the Instances Overview dashboard for instance metrics. For other instances, sometimes a only single instance is bad.
panels.title: Game Server Crashes

panels.description: #### What it means It shows the game session IDs of the crashed game sessions. Click the link of game session ARN to navigate to the Server Performance dashboard. #### Why is it important? A high number of game session crashes can cause bad player experiences along with resource waste and unwanted noise. #### How to mitigate the issue - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the Instances Overview dashboard for instance metrics. For other instances, sometimes a only single instance is bad.
panels.title: Crashed Game Sessions

panels.description:
#### What it means
It shows the number of concurrent users in a location, including all the game servers over all the instances in the location.

#### Why is it important?
- Shows player distribution
- Helps in capacity planning
panels.title: $location

panels.description: #### What it means It shows capacity utilization (%) in a location, and the percentage of game servers in use in the location. #### Why is it important? - Indicates regional balance - in case we need to add more capacity to a specific location. - Indicates bottlenecks #### What is the root cause? - Often, the game servers crash prematurely. Proactively check for the number of crashed game sessions and review the game server logs for the reason. - Check the Instances Overview dashboard for instance metrics for other instances, sometimes a only single instance is bad. #### How to mitigate the issue - Consider scaling the fleet to more numbers of instances in the location. - Consider increasing the number of concurrent processes in the runtime configuration for the fleet.
panels.title: $location

title: EC2 Fleet Overview
